ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to design programs with OO principles. How to collaborate on a software project.
It was a great course to practice programming, and it helped me learn real, applicable coding skills and Python, something that can't be said for most Yale CS classes.
i learned about object oriented programming, code design patterns, python, and c++
Learned python and about object-oriented programming design practices
Learned a lot about what I imagine industry software development is like. How to write and test good python code.

Got more familiar with the details of Python. I didn't learn a lot about design patterns, which was unfortunate as we spent around half the semester on design patterns. I probably would've learned more if I never went to class and just read the textbook instead.
I got an introduction to object-oriented programming python, and some insights into how the concepts translate across languages like c++ and java.
Intro to python + OOP concepts
This is the best Python class at Yale if you're just interested in learning how to code practically.

I learned how to code in Python in an object-oriented way, including a lot of quirks of Python that make certain things easier. I learned how to split up a problem into classes to tackle the problem in manageable pieces. I also learned a lot of design patterns to apply to common problems.
object oriented programming, python
I learned about concurrency, refactoring, a LOT about python, OOP principles, lots of design patterns, how to design unit tests, and overall how to better plan and structure code.
I learned object oriented programming techniques and pattern, as well as methods to better write and organize my code.
Learned a lot of practical skills that I know will be useful for internships such as OOP design and writing unit tests.
I learned about how to think in an object-oriented manner, structuring my code in terms of objects
I learned about classes and objects

knowledge: basic OOP concepts
skills: slightly better code design
the basics of object-oriented programming in python and design patterns. A little tkinter
Learned how to do object oriented programming
object-oriented programming in python, design patterns, unit testing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: fun psets.
Weaknesses: slow grading, poorly designed test suites, snarky professor, mismanaged and unclear course schedule.

Strengths: Very applicable, manageable workload, and great programming practice.
Weaknesses: I didn't really feel like I learned a lot, but that may have just been because of covid.
it's your standard 300-level cs course. very useful and applicable to a lot of things you build.

Strengths - material is super relevant to industry and feels immensely practical. Weaknesses - Professor Barron can be extremely disorganized which leads to assignments being pushed back and then bottling up at the end of the semester
Genuinely fun homeworks, engaging lectures, great support staff. Not sure how this course could be improved.
There are many weaknesses  teaching staff was poor and OH were almost never helpful, the professor is terrible at lecturing. Fortunately, the homeworks are doable and the tests are not very hard.

I think the course goes over incredibly useful knowledge; I can easily see how these concepts apply in the real world. I think the main drawback of the course was the online format; it made it very difficult to engage fully with the class. I think it could have been helpful to have more guidance when it came to specifics of the psets.

Strengths - great class if your goal is to get proficient at python and learn some OOP concepts along the way
Weaknesses - Organization could have been much better - when Tim says an assignment/quiz will be out "later today," that typically means sometime in the next few days. Some of the assignments seem to be focused on trying to figure out what the autograder will accept, as opposed to really understanding concepts. HW specifications could have been more clear (I'm thinking of the assignment 2? that involved a GUI and database, where a lot of edge-case behavior had to be clarified later)

Strengths: Valuable knowledge for interviews, made me a better programmer in general
Weaknesses: The workload of the course is very tail heavy. The last two psets are more work than all of the previous ones. It is also pretty difficult to pay attention in lecture with all of the raw code we go through.
assignments are strengths - enjoyed the last two psets even though they were the hardest

The strengths are definitely the psets, the weekly quizzes, and the lectures. The psets do a really great job of reinforcing the material learned in lecture. Fore example, when implementing checkers, we knew that we would be building off it for chess so I was extremely motivated to utilize the design patterns discussed in order to ensure an easier chess assignment. The weekly quizzes do a great job of keeping students up to date with lectures. If they hadn't been there, I'm afraid I would have definitely gotten behind on lectures and the quizzes force you to keep up which is great! Lastly, the lectures are extremely clear and always motivated by actual code examples to reinforce the material right after a general discussion of the topics. It's difficult to come up with many weaknesses. Perhaps having one more assignment may have been nice on concurrency but other than that this course was fantastic.
The lectures are easy to follow, the slides are concise with all the most important information, and the assignments greatly help me solidify the different design patterns we learn in class.
I felt like the last two Psets were a bit rushed in. If possible, spreading out the Psets more would make it a lot less stressful and easier to handle for students.

Professor Barron was (a) great lecturer, (b) very helpful and listened to students and was understanding, and (c) wise in teaching the class in a non-C language. I think that is everything one can hope for in a CS class, and I am super glad to have taken it. 

Only weakness, as other reviews in past semester have said, is that the class is LOTS of work in the last three weeks of the semester, but manageable otherwise, so make sure to plan accordingly.
The lectures were very thorough and the examples were helpful. Sometimes I felt like the code examples were so confusing

strengths: you learn industry skills (that you could probably learn from a book), psets are kinda fun
weaknesses: Tim Barron is a disorganized lecturer who is not attentive to his students, the psets are not designed to implement what is being taught in class, so content covered in lecture goes in through one ear and out the other

strengths: reasonable and enjoyable psets, Barron organizes his teaching in a logical manner. He is helpful in office hours. I appreciated that we were allowed to code in partnerships for the last two psets. 
weaknesses: sometimes Barron goes just a little fast. Also the workload of the class became significantly heavier in the weeks leading up to and including reading period--I would've preferred more of that work be assigned in the pretty light first couple months of the year. Personally, wouldn't recommend adding the sqlite stuff next year, unless the TAs are more familiar with it
Course material is good but the professors organization and teaching was not great

Spread out the homework assignments more, so that the harder ones (in my opinion, HW2 and HW4, have more weeks to complete them). 
Use a queue system (like CS201 or CS223) for office hours.

The strength of this course is the practicality of the subject. You learn very important concepts that are used in many software engineering settings, such as unit testing, asynchronous functions, and object-oriented design problems. Seeing live coding examples and working through them through lectures was also incredibly helpful. 

The weaknesses of this course were the weekly quizzes. While they seem like a good idea, the questions selected were kind of random and didn't really serve as a good evaluation of what was taught in the corresponding lecture. As a result, they ended up being annoying to complete. Another weakness was the pacing of the course. I felt like the beginning of the course went by extremely slowly, and we were given way too much time for some of the assignments and to learn some of the concepts. This made the end of the course feel super rushed, and the workload on the assignments ramped up suddenly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Online quizzes after each lecture helped make sure that I actually watched the lectures and grasped some of the content.
office hours in this class were actually so great. we had them over discord and they were very helpful, very fast, and i felt like i could get the help that i needed.

Recorded lectures are so much better than going back over scribbled notes, so one of the benefits of being virtual means that recorded lectures are a thing, which I find immensely helpful when reviewing for exams

Consistent quizzes were a great way of keeping us up to date with lectures. Note that while there is technically a "participation" part of the grade, that so long as you do well on quizzes you do not need to worry about that discretionary portion (Tim says this at the end of the semester). I'm not sure why this policy needs to be hidden until the end of the term, as I personally find discretionary "participation" points odd for a large CS lecture (not a seminar) where most students are asynchronous anyways.
good
The recorded lectures and slides are always provided quickly.
Lectures were elite, and Professor made quizzes for each lecture to make sure we were on top it which was really helpful
The live and recorded lectures were helpful. There were lots of office hours
N/A
I think Barron did what he could to encourage in-person attendance.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take it for the content, not the professor. I enjoyed OO a lot, but Tim is a tragedy. I learned more in this course than I did in 223, but at a higher cost to my soul.
Definitely. One of the best classes for the CS Major/Certificate. Very applicable and useful, and not too hard on the workload front.

i am a graduating senior and i wish yale cs had more courses like this - very applicable, you learn a lot of new things in this course that i've used before previously in my internships/work without even realizing that it was an oop concept. my only regret is not having taken this class sooner in my yale cs career.

This course is phenomenal. The material is extremely relevant to anyone who wants to go into software development. All of the technical interviews I have had have always involved object-oriented programming, so this course was a game changer in my understanding of those concepts (and helped me landed my first internship). Also, you get to learn Python which is just awesome. The assignments are really interesting: you create a bank application (and build a graphical user interface for it), you write test-cases for the German enigma machine, and you code checkers and chess, which are all really interesting
Definitely worth taking. A pleasant challenge but not overly difficult, and very valuable content.

Sure  the actual material covered in the textbook is quite useful and is very good to know for industry. If Tim is teaching this course, I'd recommend leaning mostly on the textbook and less on the lectures.
I might recommend this course to someone if it were not online.

Probably one of the easiest CS electives you can take, which makes sense as it recently got downgraded from a 400/500 level course to a 200 level course - with the large amount of extra credit offered at the end of the semester, getting a good grade is not hard as long as you put some effort (if that is what you are looking for)

Yes! Assignments and exams are really not bad at all, and the psets are project-like which is a really nice change from other CPSC classes I've taken. The class is taught fairly and the lectures are actually very helpful. The only downside is that we had a quiz after every lecture, though they got easier / more straightforward as the course progressed.

I would recommend this course because OOP concepts are pretty important for work in industry. However, the psets are pretty poorly structured, and the workload will ramp up significantly over the course of the semester. The quizzes after every lecture were also quite tedious and didn't really do much for my learning.
Yes, definitely. Best CS class I've taken at Yale. Coming in without a ton of outside CS experience --- it was great to spend a semester in a language like in Python.

Yes! This course is a must take for students doing programming in any field. Even if you aren't doing any programming in the future, if you have the necessary background and are looking for a fun class with fun assignments I would recommend this course. This course did not count for my major but I thoroughly enjoyed taking this course and could not recommend it more to anyone remotely interested!
yes! great CS elective that is actually super useful for internships/jobs!
Take the course if you want to improve your coding!

YES! One of the most practical classes in the CS department especially if you're interested in going into swe. The timing of the last two Psets were a bit rushed, but other than that, the workload isn't that bad and very manageable.
Yeah definitely. I'm at a point where I will only consider courses in CS taught in non-C languages and this was perfection.
Yes interesting class, but second and third psets seemed to do less with OOP but I did think learning about the enigma machine was super cool

No: The only reason you should take this class is if you're running out of CS credits and you need a gut to pad your other electives. You will not be excited or fulfilled by this course like you will other electives. I took this class because I wanted to get ahead in my credits, and I kind of regret wasting a credit on this class. Yes, you do learn industry skills...or you can read a book or watch some youtube videos to learn the same thing. Tim Barron made comments that made students feel uncomfortable asking questions and his lecture style is disorganized and only appeals to a portion of a type of learners. He may be a fantastic programmer, but that does not mean he is fit to teach students. His personal interactions with students were generally discouraging and the way he conducted the class was as well. The Fall 2020 reviews said this class was a gut and only depended on public test cases, and instead of adding more sophisticated private test cases, he just removed the public test cases. It took students forever to figure out how to read and use the auto grader because the class was purposefully opaque. He then padded the psets with extra credit to compensate for his management of the course in the beginning (I appreciated the EC but I would rather have better psets throughout). The quizzes for lectures were fine, I guess, but were annoying and motivated me to not really watch lecture (just to look out for the answers). The exams were designed for us to fail: in the first exam, Tim included a question that he knew we would get wrong. In the second exam, it was mostly on C++ even though we only have 2 lectures on it and were never asked to code in it until the final. Learn OOP another time and use your time better than I did.
Yes, overall I enjoyed it and I'm already starting to use concepts we learned in my internship this summer.
Yes, OOP is highly useful for industry, internships, and interviews.
nah
For anyone wanting to work in software development, this class is a must.

Once in a while, Prof Barron would post a pre recorded lecture if he was preoccupied.

live virtual lecture
recorded lecture

Lectures were also recorded
